title: Galliard Scandinavian, where to buy it?
content:
Matthew Carter did a Scandinavian “cut” of Galliard where the ä ö i j where corrected to fit the swedish language.

Anyone know where to buy it?

Thanks.

 [‹ First US design patent (Printing Types)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080623194042/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34804 "Go to previous forum topic") [Futura Extra Light or Ultra Light? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080623194042/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34824 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Goran Soderstrom

comments.content: Carter & Cone did it so ask question at “Info@CarterandCone.com”

Goran,

Could you comment on what was wrong with those characters before?

Sure,

When you type this: iåiäiö with Galliard (and other “older” fonts) – you clearly see that the diacritics are very much jumping up and down.

In the swedish language we use these letters alot in a different combinations and it doesnt look good if the diacritics are not adjusted (as they mostly are today in “newer” or recently updated fonts)

Type iåiäiö here:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=galliard](http://web.archive.org/web/20080623194042/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=galliard "http://www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=galliard")

And also compare Adobes garamond with other Garamonds here, on these letters.

[http://www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=garamond](http://web.archive.org/web/20080623194042/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=garamond "http://www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=garamond")

So Matthew Carter did a special Scandinavian edition of his Galliard which is called Galliard Scandinavian. There is a nice story behind it aswell, as told by my collegue Gary Newman, but he is going to tell it so much better than me so I wont even dare to try :)
